entry.title: Re: How to Link Custom CDS Data to a Standalone Form in S...
entry.content:
Hello @CarmenRuiz 

Thank you for your question.

Based on your scenario description, you want to print labels via a form linked to FDP_PP_MOR_DATA_LIST_SRV but you need to enrich it with custom Z fields from your MES CDS view.

Have a look at the following links Extending the Form Template with Custom Fields, Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic & BAdIs for Output Data Modification

  • Answer to question 1: No, only FDP released services can be linked. This means you must enrich them.
  • Answer to question 2: Yes, if your Z fields are business context oriented. You can create them as a custom field and then expose them through the data source extensions.
  • Answer to question 3: If your fields come only from MES CDS and cannot be created as CFL custom fields, then you have to implement the BAdI to enrich the form payload.

Those steps also ensure you adhere to the best practice.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Extensibility Custom Field - Professional services -...
entry.content:
Hello @Amgad-El-Stohi 

Thank you for your question.

Based on your description, there seem to be an extensibility gap with professional services to Project Billing in the public cloud. Your set up is correct, the issue seems to be that PDR to BDR handover logic does not automatically include your new custom field even though you see it in both UIs.

Consider the following links for details. Flexible Aggregation of Billing Output for Professional Services,

Managing Billing for Services, & BAdI for Billing Documents.

The blog you referenced also explains why coding block extensibility alone does not cover transfer logic.

I recommend you:

  • Check the business scenario enablement, the crucial piece here is the coding block to billing document item for project billing. Make sure this scenario is published after enabling. If not the field does not flow downstream.
  • Consider implementing a BAdI to read your custom field value from the PDR item and assign it to the BDR structure

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Wily Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 Installation
entry.content:
Customer would like to know how to install and deploy Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Wily Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 Installation
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Introscope EM 10.8 SP01 could be installed with reference of below Note/KBA:

Download Media:

Download WILYISEM01*.zip and WILYISMM01*.zip as per Note 3247270

 

Install EM SP01 and Management Module SP01 refer to KBA3578130(Windows):

Installation procedure for EM SP01:

  1. Download WILYISEM01*.zip for EM SP01.
  2. Create Installation directory of your choice (In previous versions, by default Introscope used to create and install in this directory: /usr/sap/ccms/apmintroscope). Now extract the Zip file in the installation directory. Then extract the em-sap-noinstaller-dist-*.zip in the same installation directory.
  3. Open file ca-eula*.txt in a text editor, read the license, and modify the last line to read CA-EULA=accept. If the license is not accepted installation will fail.
  4. At this point there are multiple jre directories created (example: jre-windows, jre-linux) in the installation directory. Open the command prompt from the installation directory and as per your operating select the specific jre and execute like below examples
    For windows : ‘jre-windows-x64\bin\java -jar product-configurator.jar -e ca-eula.silent.txt -r installer.properties’
    For linux : ‘jre-linux-x64/bin/java -jar product-configurator.jar -e ca-eula.silent.txt -r installer.properties’

Management Module installation steps:

  1. Download WILYISMM01*.zip and Extract into the EM installation directory.
  2. Overwrite all files while extracting Management modules
  3. Execute Osgiindex.bat/osgiindex.sh (maintain 775 permissions for this file).

Note:

*use <sid>adm user instead of root account on UNIX

*Ensure you have a Diagnostics Agent installed on the host being used for the installation

 

Change password for Introscope Enterprise Manager user as per KBA2310713:

1.run SHA2Encoder script located in the <EM_Home>/tools directory.(For Windows, SHA2Encoder.bat <password>  For UNIX, SHA2encoder.sh <password>)

2.adjusting the corresponding user line, using the generated password string (the part after colon ':') as password. An example format is:
<user name="X" password="abcdef15bcd349db90dffece73e1..."/>

 

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program – Call for participation
entry.content:
Hi Community,

 

"Improvements for HTML Control based on WebView2 (Edge)

Several enhancements have been implemented for the WebView2 based HTML Control:

  • Two new pages in SAP GUI options dialog can be used to configure the control
  • Data downloaded via the HTML Control is stored in a SAP GUI specific folder and the lifetime of this data can be managed (automatic deletion)
  • Trusted file types can be automatically launched after having been downloaded via the HTML Control
  • When ABAP applications open external browser windows, SSO can be managed without using the browser extension that is still required in release 8.00 

                       

             

      Thanks for your sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

 

Regards,

ZFiori.

 

🙂

entry.title: Re: CAP Java: No qualifying bean of type 'com.sap.cds.ser...
entry.content:
This means the service srv.invoice.archive.InvoiceArchiveConfigService and srv.invoice.form.CreateInvoiceUIService has @odata.draft.enabled annotation. The problem here is the database couldn't understand which draft is used for which. To solve this issue, specify the draft service with @Qualifier annotation and the parameter be the service's name.

@Autowired
@Qualifier("InvoiceArchiveConfigService")
private DraftService invoiceArchiveDraftService;

entry.title: Integrating SAP IBP with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud for Demand Planning Using CI-DS
entry.content:
Overview

In a two-tier ERP model, SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) acts as the centralized planning tool, while SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud serves as the transactional system at the headquarters. This guide outlines how to integrate these systems using SAP Cloud Integration for Data Services (CI-DS) to enable seamless demand planning.

Step 1: Install and Configure CI-DS in the Backend System

  1. Install CI-DS Agent on the backend system (S/4HANA Private Cloud).
  2. Configure the Data Stores in CI-DS to connect to:
    • SAP S/4HANA system (source)
    • SAP IBP system (target)

Configure “ Define Default values for data Integration Between SAP IBP and SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”

 Step 2: Activate Extractors in SAP S/4HANA

To extract master and transactional data, activate the relevant BW extractors.

 Key Transaction Codes:

TCode

Purpose

RSA9

Transfer Application Component Hierarchy

RSA5

Install SAP-delivered DataSources

RSA6

Display active DataSources

RSA3

Test data extraction

RSA7

Monitor delta queue

RSO2

Create generic DataSources

Execution Flow:

  1. RSA9 – Transfer the application component hierarchy.
  2. RSA5 – Select and install the required standard extractors.
  3. RSA6 – Confirm activation.
  4. RSA3 – Test the extractors.

Step 3: View iFlows in CI-DS

Once extractors are activated, corresponding iFlows become available in CI-DS.

  • These iFlows map the data from S/4HANA to IBP.
  • You can customize or schedule them for initial and delta loads.

Step 4: Configure SCPI in S/4HANA Private Cloud

In the S/4HANA system:

  1. Use transaction SCPI to configure the integration.
  2. Set up communication arrangements for:
    • SAP_COM_0008 – Business Partner, Customer, Supplier
    • SAP_COM_0009 – Product

Step 5: Run Initial and Delta Loads

  • Initial Load: Transfers all relevant master and transactional data.
  • Delta Load: Transfers only the changed data after the initial load.

Step 6: Integrate Master Data to IBP

  • Locations: Plants, storage locations, etc.
  • Materials: Products and product hierarchies.

 

 

Step 7: Validate and Monitor

  • Use RSA3 to test extractors.
  • Monitor CI-DS job logs for success/failure.
  • Use IBP Excel Add-In to verify data load.

entry.title: Re: aATP - Manage Substitution Locations
entry.content:
Hello @AdamHorne 

Thank you for your question.

Consider to consult KBA 3193069 & Manage Substitutions for details on how to proceed. However, the summary is, you do not need to delete and rebuild substitution rules if your scenario changes when you work with manage substitution in public cloud. Please note that each substitution rule is time-dependent. You can inactivate the rule. Thereby you stop it from being applied immediately. By maintaining an end date, the rule remains in your system for audit and reporting reference but is no longer valid after that date. You then create a new rule with the revised substitution chain. This ensures history of previous substitutions is preserved and you can track what rules were valid at different times.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Migration Guide From BOPF to RAP Business Objects
entry.content:
Introduction

With the evolution of SAP development models, Business Object Processing Framework (BOPF) is gradually being replaced by the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), which provides a more modern, cloud-ready, and Fiori-optimized approach for building business applications. To help developers transition, SAP provides a guided migration procedure that converts CDS-based BOPF Business Objects into RAP Business Objects.

This migration ensures that existing business logic, determinations, validations, and actions can be reused in the RAP model, reducing redevelopment effort while aligning applications with SAP’s strategic direction. The migration process can be executed in two modes:

  • Simulation Mode – to check the feasibility of migration and identify potential errors or warnings.
  • Migration Mode – to perform the actual migration of objects.

The following procedure outlines the step-by-step approach for performing this migration, including checking transactional processing (TP) and consumption views, handling transport requests, and reviewing logs to ensure a smooth transition.

Procedure

    1. In your ABAP project, navigate to your CDS based BOPF BO under BOPF Business Objects in the Project Explorer.        

       

       

    2. Open the context menu and choose RAP Business Object   Migrate....

       

    3. In the Migration to RAP Business Objects wizard, select any one of the following modes:
       Simulation- checks and tests for errors and warnings before performing any changes. No object is migrated productively.
       Migration- migrates all the related objects.
       

       

    4. Choose Next.
    5. Check the TP views of the business objects affected by the migration.

      The transactional processing (TP) views display the lists of CDS views containing the transactional processing enabled object model annotations.

    6. Choose Next.
    7. Check the consumption views of the business objects affected by migration.

      The consumption views display the list of CDS views containing the transactional processing delegated annotations.

    8. For migration, select or create a transport request for the objects.
    9. Choose Next.
    10. To start the simulation, choose Finish.
    11. For migration, read the disclaimer in the Disclaimer page and the linked migration documentation carefully as the migrated business object cannot be reverted.

      The simulation log is displayed in the BO Migration Log view. Please read the outcome carefully, as errors or warnings indicate additional manual adjustments after the migration.

    12. To continue with migration, select Continue Migration.
    13. Choose Finish.

The migration log is displayed in the BO Migration Log view. Please read the outcome carefully, as errors or warnings indicate additional manual adjustments after the migration.

Conclusion
Migrating CDS-based BOPF objects to RAP helps modernize applications while reusing existing logic and reducing redevelopment. Always start with simulation to identify issues, carefully review migration logs, and then proceed with the actual migration. This ensures a smooth transition to SAP’s strategic RAP model.

Hi

2. For supporting the DB MS SQL 2019, refer to the SAP Note 2807743

3.  For the SAP on Windows 2019 support, see the SAP note 2751450.

4. For the System copy, check the SAP Note 2779625. You can perform the system copy in MS SQL using the Backup the source DB and restore the DB in the newly built target system, start the SWPM process 

Regards

SS

entry.title: Re: How to save a PDF file with colors
entry.content:
Hi @Tanabe_S ,

This behavior usually happens because the Export to PDF function in the Public Cloud apps is optimized for printing data, not for preserving screen formatting. In early 2024 the export still carried over the CSS styles, but SAP changed the rendering engine in a recent upgrade, so colors and some formatting no longer get exported.

Workarounds you can try:

  • Instead of “Export to PDF,” use your browser’s Print → Save as PDF option. That captures what’s actually displayed on screen, including colors.

  • If available, switch to the “Print” icon in the app (some apps have it hidden in the ⋮ menu) rather than Export.

  • Use Microsoft Print to PDF or another PDF printer driver while printing the browser page.

  • For repeatable reports, consider Story/Analytic App in SAC where color themes are retained in export.

Until SAP updates the export rendering, the browser print-to-PDF option is the only way to reliably capture on-screen colors.

entry.title: Introducing Favorites and Recent in SAP BTP cockpit – A personalized navigation experience
entry.content:
We are happy to announce a new enhancement for the SAP BTP cockpit: Favorites and Recent. This feature provides immediate access to important resources from everywhere in the cockpit. It’s designed to help you work with more focus and productivity across the multitude of accounts, applications and services.

Why Favorites and Recent
Navigating through cockpit and finding the right access points and resources over and over again can be a tedious activity. With a growing number of subaccounts, service instances and spaces this can get even harder and it is easy to lose track of how to quickly navigate from A to B.

Favorites lets you bookmark your most important resources to save time and cognitive effort.
Recent will show you the resources you recently interacted with so you can pick up your work where you left off.

How it works

Favorites: On all main pages of the cockpit, you’ll find a favorites button on the right side. You can click it to automatically add a favorite into the favorite section. By clicking the favorite button again, the favorite will be removed from the list. Favorites are automatically grouped into resource groups (e.g. Subaccount or Space) to make it easier for orientation. For service instances and subscriptions, the favorite not only saves the page but also provides a direct link to the application or the service dashboard.

Recent: When you interact with or stay a longer period of time on a resource in the cockpit, it will be added to the recent tab. This includes a navigation path to directly access the item, a context helper with details about the subaccount and space (if applicable), and a timestamp showing when the interaction occurred.

Filter and search capabilities are both available for Favorites and Recent and will make your interactions even easier. As Favorites and Recent are now a permanent part of your side navigation, you’ll have quick access to them from anywhere in the Cockpit, keeping everything you need just one click away.

What’s Next
Your feedback makes all the difference. We’re always looking for feedback to refine and enhance the experience of SAP BTP cockpit. You can leave quick feedback via the shell bar icon in the cockpit at any given time or join our user research survey.

entry.title: Re: How to hide the table in sap adobe form based on cond...
entry.content:
Hi @Mahil ,

Wrap the table in a subform (e.g. sfTable) and hide that subform when the table has no data.

JavaScript (layout:ready of sfTable):

// hide whole block if the table has no rows or all cells are empty

var hasRows = Table1._Row1.count > 0;
var hasData = false;
if (hasRows) {
for (var i = 0; i < Table1._Row1.count; i++) {
var r = Table1.Row1[i];
if (r.Act.rawValue || r.Material.rawValue || r.Name.rawValue || r.ReqmntQty.rawValue) { hasData = true; break;
}
}
}
this.presence = hasData ? "visible" : "hidden"; 

Notes: Use layout:ready (or initialize) event.

entry.title: Re: Nested parameterised cds view
entry.content:
Hi @anil_lahori2 ,

HANA doesn’t allow nesting a parameterized view unless all parameters are passed and actually used. Your wrapper CDS is triggering the “unused parameter” error.

Quick fixes:

  • Expose the same parameters in your custom CDS and forward them with real values.

  • Or wrap the standard view in a table function (AMDP) and call it there.

  • Or use a non-parameterized view and filter with a WHERE clause instead.

This removes the SQL Code 7 error.

entry.title: Re: SAP PS - Assigning project types to the project profile not working
entry.content:
We were on S/4HANA 2021 and facing a similar issue with Project Types filtering based on Project Profile.

Follow the SAP Note 2232730: Perform the step of activating the flag PROF_PTYPE_FLG via BADI: PS_FUNCTION_SWITCH method GET_SWITCH, by setting value to 'X' (abap_true)

Then, the relevant configs must be maintained in "Assign Project Types to Project Profile".

This helped to achieve the desired filtering.

entry.title: Re: ABAP: SE41 from dict. naming advice/tip
entry.content:
Hi @jeff_broodwar ,

You can’t have multiple screen fields with “From Dict.” ticked and still keep different field names — the F4 help only works if the field name matches the DDIC reference (like MSEG-MATNR).

If you need several fields, use one reference field (From Dict, e.g. MSEG-MATNR) and then copy the value into your own screen fields, or create a table control/loop over one reference field. Another option is to assign search help manually in PBO via DYNP_VALUES_READ / F4IF_FIELD_VALUE_REQUEST for each custom field.

In short: either use the standard DDIC ref for all, or keep your own field names but code the F4 help yourself.

entry.title: 3rd level child in RAP managed scenario does not navigate to Identification facet
entry.content:
I used Parent->Child->Grandchild relationship in managed RAP Scenario and used the standard create, update, delete. I created V4 UI Service binding and checked the Preview.  All the navigation works except from the 3rd level. When I select one row of Grandchild, it does not show the Identification facet. This issue is not there in V2 UI Service.

Here is the behavior definition and Metadata extension screenshots.

managed implementation in class zbp_i_school unique;
//strict;
with draft;

define behavior for ZI_SCHOOL alias schooldetails
persistent table zschool_det
draft table zschool_det_d

lock master total etag lastchangeddate
authorization master ( instance )
etag master locallastchangeddate
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  draft action Activate optimized;
  draft action Discard;
  draft action Edit;
  draft action Resume;
  draft determine action Prepare;


  field ( readonly : update ) SchoolId;
  action ( features : instance ) setOpenStatus result [1] $self;

  association _zchild { create; with draft; }


  mapping for zschool_det
    {
      SchoolId   = school_id;
      SchoolName = school_name;
      Location   = location;
      Medium     = medium;
      OpenNow    = open_now;
    }
}

define behavior for ZI_STUDENT alias studentBD
authorization dependent by _zparent
persistent table zstudent_det
draft table zstudent_det_d
lock dependent by _zparent
{

  update;
  delete;

  association _zparent { with draft; }
  association _zgchild { create; with draft; }


  field ( readonly : update ) SchoolId;
  field ( readonly : update ) StudentId;

  mapping for zstudent_det
    {
      StudentId   = student_id;
      SchoolId    = school_id;
      StudentName = student_name;
      Birthdate   = birthdate;
    }
}

define behavior for ZI_SCORE alias scoreBD
authorization dependent by _zparent
persistent table zscore_det
draft table zscore_det_d
lock dependent by _zparent
{

  update;
  delete;

  association _zchild { with draft; }
  association _zparent { with draft; }

  field ( readonly : update ) SchoolId;
  field ( readonly : update ) StudentId;
  field ( readonly : update ) SubjectId;
  field ( readonly : update ) Class;

  mapping for zscore_det
    {
      Class       = class;
      SchoolId    = school_id;
      StudentId   = student_id;
      SubjectId   = subject_id;
      SubjectName = subject_name;
      Marks       = marks;
    }

}
@Metadata.layer: #CORE

@UI: { headerInfo: { typeName: 'Subject', typeNamePlural: 'Subjects',
                     title: { type: #STANDARD, label: 'Subject Det Title', value: 'SubjectName' } } }
annotate view ZC_SCORE with
{

  .facet: [ { position: 10, label: 'Score Detail', purpose: #STANDARD,
                     type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE } ]


  : { lineItem: [{ position: 10, label: 'Subject ID' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Subject ID'  }]  }
  SubjectId;

  : { lineItem: [{ position: 20, label: 'Class' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 20, label: 'Class'  }]  }
  Class;

  : { lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Student ID' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Student ID'  }]  }
  StudentId;


  : { lineItem: [{ position: 40, label: 'School ID' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 40, label: 'School ID'  }]  }
  SchoolId;

  : { lineItem: [{ position: 50, label: 'Subject Name' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 50, label: 'Subject Name'  }]  }
  SubjectName;


  : { lineItem: [{ position: 60, label: 'Score' }],
                      identification: [{ position: 60, label: 'Score'  }]  }
  Marks;

}

Please let me know what I am missing? Let me know if you need more code details.

entry.title: Re: Business Rule : How can I round the amount into integ...
entry.content:
I believe you can use the round option, follow the instructions on the link: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/implementing-business-rules-in-sap-successfactors/round?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

You should be able to divide by 10, use the precision 0 (no decimal numbers), and control the rounding using the threshold. Then multiply by 10 to return to the amount. 

the math:

101632.40 / 10 = 10163.24

round (10163.24, precision =0, threshold = 0.001) = 10163.00

10163.00 * 10 = 101630.00

Depending on the rank, you can choose to add 5 (rank 2) or divide initially by 100 and multiply by 100 at the end (rank 3)

entry.title: Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The extensibility expert right next to you
entry.content:
Extensibility Assistant for Key Users: The extensibility expert right next to you

Have you ever been in a situation

  • where you had to create or maintain a key user custom field or create some key user custom logic but wondered which business context, which OData service, which SOAP service, or in general which object you must extend out of the thousands of potential candidates?
  • or where you must figure out which CDS view you should choose as value help provider for your key user custom field out of the thousands of options?
  • or where you know the UI or API service to which you need to add an extension field, but you have no idea which business context or data source needs to be extended?

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you’ll meet the GenAI-driven Extensibility Assistant, which helps you to master such challenges. Starting with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, the extensibility assistant is available in the Custom Fields Fiori app and in the Custom Logic Fiori app.

You’ll learn how to make the extensibility assistant available in your system and for your user and how to use it.

How to make the extensibility assistant available in your system and for your user

The extensibility assistant belongs to the feature set of Joule for Developers (J4D) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The first step you need to take to make the extensibility assistant available in a system is to “activate” J4D for the system. How this can be done is described in SAP Note 3571857. You can find more information regarding J4D in general (also regarding the licensing) here: https://www.sap.com/documents/2025/02/b4f714de-f57e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html

Please note that the GenAI-driven extensibility assistant is only available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and only in systems where development is supported:

  • In 3-system landscapes, this is the development system

Once J4D is activated for your system, you need to assign the business catalog SAP_A4C_BC_DEV_AIQ_PC to your user. Please note that you need to use client 100, as the key user extensibility apps are only available there.

You can assign the business catalog in various ways:

  1. copy the extensibility template business role SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC to your own role and assign this copied role to your user. You can refer to Maintain Business Roles for further details on how to maintain business roles
  2. assign the business catalog SAP_A4C_BC_DEV_AIQ_PC to another custom business role that you assign to your user

As soon as the business catalog SAP_A4C_BC_DEV_AIQ_PC is assigned to your user, the button “Open Assistant” will be active in the Custom Logic and the Custom Fields Fiori app (see screenshots below).

Open Assistant button in Custom Fields and Custom Logic Fiori app

If it turns out that though you followed all the steps described above  still the "Open Assistant" button does not occur please create a customer ticket on application component BC-SRV-APS-EXT-FLD.

How to use the extensibility assistant in the Custom Fields Fiori app.

When you click “Open Assistant” in the Custom Fields Fiori app, the extensibility assistant pops up (see screenshot below):

Initial screen of the extensibility assistant in the Custom Fields Fiori app

You can now enter your question or your request in the text box located under the “Your Question” label.

You’ll notice a question mark icon next to the “Your Question” label. Clicking the question mark, a popup appears explaining you how to interact with the extensibility assistant, providing you recommendations when it comes to how to formulate your questions, and showing you a set of example questions (see screenshot below):

Explanation popup of the extensibility assistant in the Custom Fields Fiori app

To understand in detail how to interact with the extensibility assistant, let’s have a look at a concrete example. Let’s assume that you were told to create a custom field which should capture an UPS tracking number of parcels belonging to specific sales orders. The field should be included in the OData API for Customer Return documents, as this information is essential for communication with another company.
In general, let’s say that you know the Custom Fields Fiori app, and you know how to create a custom field (by pressing the + button on the upper left corner of the Custom Fields app).
What you’ll most likely not know is which business context you have to choose out of the more than 500 available ones. You most likely also won’t know the exact name of the OData API in which you should enable the field.

That is where the extensibility assistant comes in handy. The scenario mentioned above usually consists of the following steps:

1. You enter your question or your request into the question text box. In this case, the text we enter is “Create a field UPSTrackingNumber and enable it for the customer return OData API”. As soon as you’ve entered the text and pressed the return button (or clicked on the arrow button on the right), the assistant’s answer is shown in the “Assistant Response” text box. It might be for example “I found multiple business contexts related to "customer return". Please choose one of the following options:”. Please note that on the lower right corner of the “Assistant Response” text box, there is a link to “References”. Opening the link, you’ll get a list of SAP documentation links like Fiori Apps Library links, Business Accelerator Hub links, and others which have been the knowledge source of the assistant’s answer. You can click on these links to navigate to these documents. Within the “Assistant Proposal” box, there are business contexts shown which are relevant to the context of your question. You can simply choose one of them by pressing the select button on the right side of the respective option (see screenshot below).

Select business context

In our case, the UPSTrackingNumber field belongs to the header of the Sales Order document. We’ll choose the business context SD_SALESDOC with the description “Sales: Sales Document”.
Note that the extensibility assistant shows a relevance score telling you how relevant the finding is in the context of your question.

2.As soon as you’ve selected the respective business context, the extensibility assistant responds for example “I found multiple OData APIs related to customer return. Please choose one of the following options to enable the custom field:”. You’ll see a list of OData API options from which you can choose. Please note that in this case, a column “Documentation” is shown which allows you to navigate directly to the documentation of the respective OData API to validate whether this is really the API you were looking for (see screenshot below).

Select OData API
In this case, you select the second-best option, as you prefer to use an OData V2 service and not its OData V4 variant.

3. As soon as you’ve selected the OData API option, the extensibility assistant responds for example “The custom field UPSTrackingNumber has been prepared for enabling in the OData API Customer Return (A2X) - V2 (API_CUSTOMER_RETURN_SRV~1). Please make sure to save the changes to make them permanent. If you need any further assistance, feel free to ask!” and proposes an action which you can see in the “Proposed Action” box on the bottom of the extensibility assistant pop-up (see screenshot below).

Proposed Create custom field action

You can now check whether the proposal of the assistant fits your needs and if so, you can simply click “Accept” on the lower right side of the “Proposed Action” box. With that, the data is handed over to the “Create Field” screen of the Custom Fields app (see screenshot below).

Proposal taken over from the extensibility assistant to the “New Field” popup

You can check the data once again and change it if needed. There is always a human in-between, and the extensibility assistant never does something on its own within the system.

Please note that instead of clicking “Accept”, you can continue to chat with the extensibility assistant as it remembers the conversation history. You can, for example, ask the extensibility assistant “Why did you choose a length of 50 for this field” and in the “Assistant Response” the assistant will answer for example “The length of 50 for the custom field UPSTrackingNumber was chosen as a reasonable default to accommodate typical tracking numbers, which can vary in length depending on the carrier and format. If you have specific requirements or need a different length, please let me know, and I can adjust it accordingly!”.
You can also ask the assistant to enable the field in further usages like APIs or SOAP services, or any other available location.

Now, we’ve used the extensibility assistant to master our UPSTrackingNumber challenge, where the assistant helped us to identify the correct business context and propagate the field to the OData API where we needed it to be.
The extensibility assistant supports the following scope:

  • Create Custom Fields: It can create new custom fields in various business contexts.
  • Find Business Contexts: It can help you find the right business context to extend for your custom fields.
  • Find Usages: It can identify where custom fields can be used, such as in UIs, APIs, CDS views, transactions, etc.
  • Enable Usages: It can enable custom fields in identified usages (note that email or form templates are not supported).
  • Find Business Scenarios: It can find business scenarios that involve data flow between different business objects.
  • Find Existing Custom Fields: It can locate existing custom fields in specific business contexts.
  • Find Value Helps: It can find value helps that can be used in custom fields.

How to use the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic Fiori app

Just like in the Custom Fields Fiori app, you can click “Open Assistant” in the Custom Logic Fiori app, which opens the extensibility assistant (see screenshot below):

Initial screen of the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic Fiori app

You can now enter your query to find an extension point in the text box located under the “Your Question” label. As this assistant helps with finding extension points, it’s recommended to enter a query where you outline what you want your implementation to do. As soon as you have formulated your query, you can press enter or click the send button. After a short wait, you are prompted with extension points that fit your query.

Currently, the assistant doesn’t support code generation but can only be used to find the correct extension point for your use case. If you are unsure of what the assistant can do, you can ask “What can you do?” to get an answer. In the following section, you find an example on when and how to use the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic Fiori app.

Imagine you get a new requirement for your bill of materials that you need to implement. If your new requirement is not met, the bill of materials should not be saved. To find the extension point that lets you insert custom checks, you tell the assistant “I want to validate my BOM before it is saved”. Once entered, the assistant prompts you with multiple extension points that might fit your use case (as you can see in the screenshot below):

Extensibility assistant after entering a query

List of references that contain further information and documentation

To choose the right extension point, you can have a look at the extension point’s documentation or further documents about the shown extension points. You can find that information by clicking the “References” link under the assistant’s response. There, you’ll find a list of links that will open the resource in your browser. If you click on the extension point’s documentation, a popup will open containing said documentation. Additionally, you will find the extension point’s documentation by clicking the link “View Documentation” in the table.

Popup with the extension point’s documentation

Once you’ve chosen the right extension point, you can select it from the list and click on “Create Implementation”. This will direct you to the creation wizard (see screenshot below). There, the extension point will already be selected for you. From there, you can create the implementation just like you would normally. If you can’t create an implementation for the selected extension point because it can only be implemented once, you get a warning that tells you which implementation already exists for the selected extension point.

Extension point table after selection

Warning if the extension point is already implemented

Now, we’ve successfully used the extensibility assistant in the Custom Logic Fiori app. The extensibility assistant in this app supports the following scope:

  • Find BAdIs: I can find the right BAdI for your custom implementation.

It currently does not support code generation.

Please note that the extensibility assistant is only available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition so far. The intention is to also make it available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, but we can’t share any timeline regarding that yet.

Now, you are done! Congratulations!
You successfully used the extensibility assistant to master challenges with key user custom fields and key user custom logic. You have an idea about the scope of the assistant so that you know what it can do for you, and you know what comes next.
